plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A popular deciduous flowering tree or shrub known for its large, fragrant, tulip-shaped flowers that appear in early spring, often before the leaves fully emerge.
plants.location: Temperate regions of North America, Europe, and Asia
plants.funFact: Saucer Magnolia flowers can be large enough to fit in the palm of your hand and are often among the earliest big blooms signaling the arrival of spring.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: An evergreen shrub widely cultivated in warm climates, producing clusters of delicate, funnel-shaped flowers with a sweet scent and glossy, lance-shaped leaves.
plants.location: Mediterranean basin, southern United States, and parts of Asia
plants.funFact: Despite its beauty, all parts of the oleander plant are highly toxic if ingested, containing cardiac glycosides.

plants.name: Erythrina crista-galli
plants.description: A deciduous tree or shrub native to South America, notable for its bright red, spiky flowers resembling a rooster's comb, attracting hummingbirds and insects.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring to early summer (October to December in Southern Hemisphere)
plants.location: Argentina, Uruguay, southern Brazil; blooms in late April in some subtropical areas of Northern Hemisphere cultivation
plants.funFact: The Cockspur Coral Tree is the national flower of Argentina and Uruguay, cherished for its striking flowers and shade-providing canopy.

plants.name: Anemone coronaria
plants.description: A herbaceous perennial that produces vividly colorful poppy-like flowers atop slender stems, popular both as a garden and wildflower.
plants.funFact: Anemone coronaria flowers close at night and on cloudy days, opening again with sunlight, a behavior known as nyctinasty.
